title: How to Take a Spirometry Test

steps.title: Avoid activities which might affect your normal lung function.
steps.content: Avoid activities which might affect your normal lung function. To ensure accurate results, you need to take the following precautions in the hours leading up to the test [2] X Research source [3] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source : Ask your healthcare provider which medications you should avoid on the day of the test. Do not smoke within 24 hours of the test. Do not drink alcohol within 4 hours of the test. Do not exercise strenuously within 30 minutes of the test. Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to breathe easily. Do not eat a heavy meal within two hours of the test.

steps.title: Report smoking and medical history to the medical staff.
steps.content: Report smoking and medical history to the medical staff. A history of smoking, chronic coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath are a few of the symptoms that are important for the medical staff to consider as they analyze your spirometry test results. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Watch the demonstration by the medical staff.
steps.content: Watch the demonstration by the medical staff. They may show you one or more breathing techniques that you will use during the test. Pay attention to the type of breaths they take and be ready to try them yourself. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Continue breathing normally through your mouth once the soft clip is placed on your nose.
steps.content: Continue breathing normally through your mouth once the soft clip is placed on your nose. This clip closes your nostrils, ensuring that all of the air you expel during the test will exit through your mouth to be measured by the spirometer. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Wrap your lips tightly around the mouthpiece.
steps.content: Wrap your lips tightly around the mouthpiece. A tight seal is necessary to prevent air leakage.It is important that all the air you are about to exhale goes into the spirometer for accurate measurements. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Take as deep a breath as possible.
steps.content: Take as deep a breath as possible. Your lungs should feel filled to their maximum. [8] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Exhale hard and fast.
steps.content: Exhale hard and fast. Think of this as trying to get all of your air out as quickly as possible. It is important that you exhale quickly for an accurate measurement of the volume you can expel within the first second. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Continue exhaling, until no more air will come out.
steps.content: Continue exhaling, until no more air will come out. Your lungs and throat should feel empty. It is important that you discharge all the air for an accurate measurement of how much you exhaled in one entire breath. [10] X Trustworthy Source American Lung Association Nonprofit health organization dedicated to improving lung health through education, advocacy, and research Go to source

steps.title: Breathe normally between attempts.
steps.content: Breathe normally between attempts. The test can make you feel lightheaded, so make sure to breathe evenly when appropriate to prevent dizziness. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Breathe using the same pattern you did during the practice test.
steps.content: Breathe using the same pattern you did during the practice test. Although breathing this way may feel unnatural, this pattern allows the spirometer to measure pulmonary functions such as lung capacity and airflow.

steps.title: Listen to any notes the medical staff give you on your breathing pattern.
steps.content: Listen to any notes the medical staff give you on your breathing pattern. You might need to increase your inhalation, the speed of your exhalation, or the duration of your exhalation for the next attempt.

steps.title: Repeat the breathing pattern at least 2 times, with breaks in between.
steps.content: Repeat the breathing pattern at least 2 times, with breaks in between. Multiple measurements give you a chance to correct performance errors, and provide the necessary data for the test results. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Wait a few days to hear from your referring doctor.
steps.content: Wait a few days to hear from your referring doctor. The medical professional who administered the test may not be able to give you the results right away. It depends on the type of medical professional who is administering the test. You may have to wait to speak with your doctor about the results after they’ve been reviewed by a specialist. [13] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Review the results with your doctor.
steps.content: Review the results with your doctor. Your height, weight, age, and sex are some of the variables the specialist considered when comparing your test results against the standard measurements. Your doctor should be able to answer questions about how these variables factored into their diagnosis. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Create a treatment plan if you’ve been diagnosed with a condition.
steps.content: Create a treatment plan if you’ve been diagnosed with a condition. Diagnoses may include asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, cystic fibrosis, pulmonary fibrosis, chronic bronchitis, emphysema, [15] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source [16] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source . Test results might also be used to determine eligibility for surgery. Your doctor will work with you to determine the right medications and lifestyle changes necessary to maintain and improve your pulmonary health.
